awd_titl_txt: Picturing the faces of stars: limb-darkening models vs. interferometer measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made to study hundreds of stars with optical interferometry and spectroscopy. Interferometry combines light waves from different telescopes and produces very high angular resolution images. This allows astronomers to record the brightness variations across a stellar disk. The center shows deeper and warmer layers of a star, whereas the edges show shallower and cooler material. This effect is called limb-darkening. The group will also record optical spectra, which measure light emitted or absorbed by individual chemical elements.  This enables derivation of fundamental parameters of the stars not already provided by interferometry, such as overall stellar luminosity, and chemical composition. All the data will be used to determine stellar diameters and temperature profiles and to test stellar astrophysics models. The data and modeling codes will be released to a public database. Two graduate students will be trained in both interferometric and modeling techniques.

The team will use the NPOI (Naval Prototype Optical Interferometer) and CHARA (Center for High Angular Resolution Array) interferometers to obtain sub-milliarcsecond resolution images. They will collect moderate-resolution optical spectroscopy with Apache Point Observatory and Georgia State University telescopes.  They will use several atmospheric models to explore three-dimensional effects and non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) effects. The project will run precise model grids for a hundred stars and at least three different models. The stellar atmosphere model code SATLAS will be made fully open-source with updated microphysics and NLTE refinements. This code and the 3D radiative hydrodynamic STAGGER will be accelerated by Graphic Processor Units through partnerships with industry collaborators.

por.por_cntn:
Limb-darkening is the reduction of apparent surface brightness towards the edge of the stellar disk (the limb). This can be seen in images of the Sun as a gradual decrease of the stellar intensity when going from the center to the limb. Limb darkening is in fact due to a combination of two factors: 1) the decrease of the temperature of the photosphere with increasing distance from the center of the star and 2) of the decreasing optical depth (the opacity of the star). Hence the disk center then shows deeper and warmer layers, whereas the edges show shallower and cooler material. The center-to-limb variation of the Sun has been known for many years and has been measured at different wavelengths, leading  to  a  plethora  of  theoretical  works  that  have  improved  our  knowledge  of  the  external layers of the Sun. But while limb darkening can be measured on the Sun via imaging, no single telescope is powerful enough to directly make similar measurements on other stars. Consequently astronomers have until now relied on stellar atmosphere models to determine the temperature variation with depth in the external layers of the star, thus predicting different amount of limb darkening for different stars. Note that providing proper constraints on limb-darkening is critical for all techniques where the stellar disk constitutes a background over which we wish to detect signal, such as in the case of characterization of transiting planets.

In parallel to the development of models, the technique of long-baseline optical interferometry -- that uses several telescopes together to directly measures the brightness distribution of stellar surfaces -- has improved dramatically. It now routinely produces measurements and even reconstructed images of stellar disks, at much higher resolution than any single telescope. The idea at the core of our proposal was to confront interferometric observations to predictions made by the latest models of limb darkening, both at infrared and visible wavelengths in stars with diverse atmospheric properties. Indeed, optical interferometry is currently one of the only few techniques that enables unambiguous measurements of such profiles.

The work supported by this grant has been confronting prediction of stellar limb-darkening made by 1D and 3D model atmospheres to actual intensity profiles measured with optical interferometric data.  Our stated objective in theoriginal NSF proposal was to collect limb-darkening profiles of more than 100 stars of diverse types. We organized several campaigns of observations between 2017 and 2019, using the PAVO instrument (R-band) and CLIMB instrument (H- and K-band) at the Center forHigh Angular Resolution Astronomy (CHARA), operated by Georgia State University, as well as the Navy Precision Optical Interferometer (V-band) operated with the US  Naval Research Laboratory and Lowell Observatory support.

We obtained several key results:

• the demonstration that measuring limb-darkening is feasible on a routine basis with current optical interferometers with a precision and an accuracy sufficient to confront measurements to models. Indeed we needed to make sure that our data analysis we did was correct, and that we were not misled by faulty observations. In particular we wanted to determine the uncertainties on our estimates of limb darkening from interferometric data.

• our observations consistently show observational evidence for systematically lower limb-darkening than predicted from even cutting edge algorithms. The discrepancy is very significant, and way outside the expected uncertainties.  Although we suspected models may not always match the data – hence why we proposed this grant in the first place – this level of discrepancy was completely unexpected.

• a first investigation of the discrepancy. We have found trends in how the discrepancies between models and observations vary with properties such as effective temperature, the gravity and the metallicity of the star. To clearly establish these trends however, we probably need even more stars than what we were able to achieve for the duration of this grant (Covid-19 effectively prevented our 2019-2021 observations from taking place).

This project has supported directly or indirectly the research carried out by one undergraduate and four graduate students at Georgia State University. In addition, following the spirit of open science, we:

• developped several open source tools to analyze interferometric data, available not only to the astronomical community but also to any interested members of the public.

• started curating a list of stars with their limb darkening profiles that we will be making available as a Vizier catalog. This database can serve as a starting point for experts on stellar atmosphere modeling to improve the predictions of their models.

More work is definitely needed in the same area to finally solve these mysterious discrepancies, and consequently we are now envisioning a follow-up study.
